div.head: The Egyptian Gazette An English Daily Newspaper, Established 1830. Editor andManager : R. Snelling. Price: One Plastre Tariff. MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 85, 1905. THE PRESS AND FOREIGN ARMIES
div.p: The recent outbreak in German Beat Africa has caused considerable annoyance to the German tax payer, already irritated by the failure of General von Trotha to suppress the Hereto revolt, and it is not surprising that voices have been raised among the Socialists and Radicals demanding that German South West Africa should be sold or ceded as soon as possible to any power that will be good enough to take a most unpleasant burden from the taxpayers’ back. At present, how- ever, the South West African Colony is not a tempting acquisition. A poor country at the best of times, and composed mainly of the “very light soil” to which the late Lord Salisbury rather unkindly referred when dis- cussing French colonial expansion in North Africa, it has been swept bare by savage in surgents and punitive columns for close on two years, and its population decimated by war and disease A number of statements concerning German atrocities have recently appeared in the home Press, and we have been surprised to find that some of our responsible organs, in their horror at the severity of German methods, have quite forgot- ten that the Indian Mutiny, and at a much later date the rising in Maahonaland, were not quelled by any but the sternest measures. In a war with savages who take no prisoners, and lose no chance of gratifying their most barbarous instincts, severity becomes necessary, and in our opinion the laws of Euro- pean war, which are excellently adapted for combat between civilised powers, cannot be applied to campaigns in which one of the com- batant forces is composed of barbarians. We do not suggest the Infliction of cruel and savage punishments—cruelty degrades, how- ever great the provocation—but there is un- pleasant work that cannot be left undone in such a campaign. Wolves are picturesque animals but they have to be extirpated. Gene- ral von Trotha no doubt issued most blood- thirsty proclamations unworthy of a civilised man, but we have seen nothing in the Cape papers, which are far better informed about the program of the straggle than is our home Press, that can justify the accusations of wholesale massacre that have appeared in responsible British journals. This taste for sensation-mongering at the expense of foreign armies is one of the greatest weaknesses of our Press, which does not appear to realise that soldiers, whatever their nationality, object to being termed savages and butchers. During the unhappy Dreyfus affair the French army was described in terms that left no doubt in the mind of the British reader that the Re- publican forces were composed of frightened peasants command by ruffians and perjurers. A few years pass and John Ball reading his description of the French maneuvres beams over the endurance and good humour of the rank and file, and notes with approval that ths average French officer knows his work well and does his best tor the comfort of his men. At present the German army is the Press- man's butt and lieutenant Bilse, a junior officer devoid of taste and expression, is held to have written the last word on the Kaiser’s forces. Some epauletted Gamaliel, blessed perhaps with less than Bilse’s endowments,will no doubt furnish our leader-writers with material for a campaign against the army of the next nation with which we happen to be on bad terms. Bat if we mast have foreign opponents, it is not possible to follow the Japanese example and keep quiet Otherwise in the unhappy event of our taking pert in a European war, we shall have to thank our journalists for im- parting a horrible bitterness to the struggle.

div.head: CARLSTAD CONFERENCE satisfactory settlement. TROOPS WITHDRAWN FROM FRONTIER
div.p: Stockholm, September 23 The Carlstad conference terminated this evening. It js officially announced that an agreement has been reached. The Protocols will be published next week. Orders have given simultaneously here and at Christiania to withdraw the troops from the frontier.
Karlstad, September 23. The Swedish and Norwegian commissioners have arrived at an understanding.

Stockholm, September 24. Though the terms of the Carlstad settlement are as yet unpublished, the comments Swedish and Norwegian press radical Norway yielded on the question of the demolition of her frontier fortresses. Sweden consented to the conclusion of an arbitration treaty. The Norwegian papers urge the people to accept the terms with self control, and rejoice that they peacefully become a sovereign nation. An extraordinary session of the Swedish Riksdag to be held on the 2nd Octo- ber will confirm the dissolution.

div.head: CHOLERA AT BERLIN.
div.p: Berlin, September 24. A largeman from Posen has died of cholers here. Great precautions are being taken. (R.)

div.head: THE BAKU TROUBLES. DISAFFECTION SPREADING.
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 24. The beginning of an agitation at the Donetz and Dombrovo coal-basins is notified and fresh disasters at Baku are anticipated. (H.)
Baku, September 24. The Tartars and Armenians have signed the peace. (Havas)

div.head: BOMB OUTRAGE IN CHINA. NINE PERSONS INJURED.
div.p: Pekin, September 24. A bomb was thrown at the train carrying the commissioners charged with studying foreign parliaments. Nine persons were wound- ed and the man who threw the bomb was killed. (Havas)

div.head: THE PEACE TERMS. LA PEROUSE STRAITS
div.p: Tokio, September 23. There is great indignation in Japan because it has transpired that the treaty binds Japan not to fortify La Perouse Straits. (Reuter

div.head: RUSSIAN TROOPS FOR TURKESTAN
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 24. The military districts of Kieff and Odessa are preparing the immediate dispatch of troops to Turkestan. (Reuter)

div.head: THREE TOWNS SURRENDER TO TURKS
div.p: London, September 24. Reuter’s Agency learns from Hodeida that the towns of Aoran, Tajela, and Kankaban surrendered to the Turks with rifles and guns. (Reuter)

div.head: AFTER THE EARTHQUAKE. TERRIBLE THUNDERSTORMS
div.p: Catanzaro, September 23. Terrible thunderstorms and torrential rains in the region devastated by the earthquake are increasing the distress and hindering the work of rehousing the sufferers. (Reuter)

div.head: RETVISAN REFLOATED
div.p: Port Arthur, September 23. The battleship Retvisan has been refloated. (Reuter)
Tokio, September 23. The battleship Retvisan has been refloated. (Havas

div.head: M. WITTE’S CONFERENCE
div.p: Paris, September 23. M. Witte left for Berlin after conferring with Prince Von Radon and M. Rouvier (Havas)
Berlin, Septemer 24. M. Witte has conferred with Baron de Richten. (havas)

div.head: HUNGARIAN CRISIS. EMPEROR SUMMONS DIET. leaders pessimistic
div.p: Vienna, September 23. The Emperor Francis Joseph desiring to make a final attempt to restore the constitu- tional regime in Hungary summoned here the leaders of the opposition, who form the ma- jority of the diet. He requested them to form a Cabinet but positively declined to entertain any modification affecting the union of Australia and Hungary or the army. He also warned them earnestly of the responsibility they would incur if they should continue to adhere to their old standpoint, and referred them to Count Goluchowski whom they declined to see because he is not a Hungarian. Count Erizaky has therefore been appointed to conduct the negotiations. (Reuter)
Vienna, September 23. The Emperor has charged M. Erizaky to negotiate with the Hungarian union. (Havas)
Vienna September 24 The Hungarian leaders are pessimistic. They say that the will of the nation must prevail over that of the Crown. (Reuter)

div.head: MOSCOW STUDENTS REVOLUTIONARY MOVEMENT.
div.p: Moscow, September 23. ixteen hundred students have decided to convert the university into a revolutionary meeting place. (Havas)
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in Ein esh Shems during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 27th inst., will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Alexandria Municipality
div.p: We shou’d like to call tho attention of our readers to the important notice issued by the Municipal authorities, which appears on our fourth page.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 13 vessels passed through the Canal on the 21st inst., 8 of which were British, 3 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Turkish. The day’s receipts amounted to fra. 389,549.01, K making the total from the 1st inst frs. '8 5,837,050.25.

div.head: Bovine Typhus
div.p: A report having reached the Sanitary Department from the Oasis of Dahla in the Asaiout district that some sus- picions cases of illness amongst the cattle had occurred there recently, a native veterinary in- spector has been sent to the spot to ascertain whether the cases are bovine typhus or not.

div.head: St. Mary Schools, Cairo
div.p: The Rev. N. Odeh, Head Master of St. Mary’s Schools, has returned to Cairo. Tbe English staff of the schools has recently been increased and it is hoped that the educational results of the next scholastic year will equal or surpass those of the last, when three of the pupils obtained secondary certificates.

div.head: A New Award
div.p: The jury of Liege, con- r firming the decision of the St. Louis committee, has placed the Berlitz School hors concours for the remarkable books for teaching languages published by Mr. Berlitz. This high distinc- tion sets the celebrated method on a level with the most remarkable inventions of the human mind. The brilliant results obtained in teach- ing languages by means of the system as much in Egypt as in Europe is moreover an evident proof of this. 26470-1

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: Only one fresh case of plague occurred in Egypt throughout last week, namely at Alexandria, and all other places are declared free. Three Europeans recovered during this period and there were two deaths, and one fresh case, an Italian grocer of the Menshieh district was notified yesterday. There are now only two cases under treatment. The total number of cases from January 1 to date amounts to 258, as compared with 804 daring the corresponding period of last year. In consequence of the notification of a fresh case at Alexandria, the quarantine measures against departures from this port have been re-established.

div.head: The Great Earthquake in Calabria
div.p: The disastrous earthquake which occurred in the early morning of the 8th inst. at Catanzaro Calabria, South Italy, was clearly recorded by the Milne seismograph at the Helouan ob- servatory. The first small tremors occurred at 3h. 48 1/2 m. a.m. (Egyptian standard time) followed by two maxima at 4h. 1 1/2 m. and 4 h. 5 m. respectively. The two large waves produced an amplitude of 9 millimetres of movement of the seismograph pendulum and were followed by small tremors lasting till 5h. 30m. As Egyptian time is one hour before Italian time and the shock in Italy was felt at 5 minutes to 8 a.m Italian time, the distur- bance appears to have been conveyed through the earth’s crust from Calabria to Helouan in about 6 minutes.

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE NOTES.
THE KHEDIVE'S VISIT.
div.p: The fetes in honor of H.H. the Khedive’s visit continue. On Saturday evening the Sol- tan gave a gala banquet for which the Khedive and his brother Prince Mohamed Ali, with the Khedivial mihmandars and suite arrived in special court carriages, escorted by Captain Hassan Bey, A.D.C. to tho Sultan, and two officers of the palace guard. The grand Vizier and the other ministers and high dignitaries of the court were also present at the banquet, which was enlivened by the strains of the court orchestra. The banquet was followed by a theatrical performance at the Imperial palace, after which H.H the Khedive took leave of his august host and drove to Bebek.

div.head: NEW RAILWAY TIME TABLE.
div.p: The winter time table will come into opera- from next Sunday, 1st October.

The times of departure of the two morning expresses from Cairo will remain the same as during tho summer months, at 7.30 and 9.30 o’clock. The midday express, with restaurant car attached, will be resumed from that date The hours of the two afternoon expresses will be 4 o’clock and 4.50, and the time of depar- ture of the night train, with sleeping car attached, will in futnre be at 11.30, a quarter of an hour later than at present.

From Alexandria the two morning expresses will start as at present, at 7 and 9 o’clock and the afternoon ones at 3.40 and 4.25. The midday train with restaurant car attached will also resume running. The last train from Alexandria for Cairo will be at 11.30 p.m The hours of departure of the trains from Cairo to Port Said will remain as before, at 7 and 11 am. and G.15 p.m. whilst from Port- Said the times have been altered to 8.10 a.m and 12.30 and 6.45 p.m.
On the Upper Egypt line there will be no change with the exception of the morning itrain from Luxor for Cairo, which will leave at 6.10 instead of 5.30 o’clock as at present.
The Railway Administration have issued the new time tables for the whole of the lines in pocket form. These can be purchased at all the booksellers for the small sum of P.T. 1.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT LTD.
div.p: Orders in connection with the telephone equipment of the Nile-Khargeh railway have been placed by the Corporation. The work is being executed by J. E and S. Spencer Ltd., F. W. Smith an dCo. and the General Electric Co. Ltd.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut. Colonel C.J. Markham and Officers, the band of the 1st Batts. King’s Royal Rifles will perform the following program of music at the Esbekieh Gardens tomorrow, Tuesday evening, com- mending at 0 o’clock. 1. March-Whistling Rufus-Mills 2. Overturo-La Sirene-Auber. 3. Selection-The Duchess of Dantzic-Caryll 4. Gavotte-Stephanie-Ozilbulka 5. Song (Kuphenium Solo, Soloist Cap. Geo. Steer), I’ll Sing thee Songs of Araby (From the Cantata Lalla Bookh)-Clay. 6. Selection (No 2)-Il Trovatore-Verdi 7. Valsse-Angelo mio-Pecorini 8 Idyll-Die Mühle im Schwarzwald-Kilenberg. Regimental March-Khedivial Anthem God Save the King. Thomas Brown, Bandmaster.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Tbe Moss liner Menes arrived on Saturday afternoon from Liverpool viA Gibraltar and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Messageries Maritimes mail boat Senegal, which left Marseilles on tho 21st inst., passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday, and is due at Alexandria to-morrow.
The Ellerman S.S. Sardinia sailed from Alexandria on Saturday for Liverpool direct with general cargo, including 2,712 bales of cotton.
The S.S. Ocean Prince left Manchester on Friday with passengers and general cargo and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about October 8.

div.head: LUNACY IN EGYPT. INCREASED ACCOMODATION NECESSARY.
div.p: The Sanitary Administration has decided upon the erection of a new lunatic asylum in re’s one of the larger towns of the Delta. The plans and estimates are being prepared, and will be submitted for the consideration and sanction of the Finance Ministry soon after the return of Sir Horace Pinching.

In consequence of the large increase og recent years in the number of patients, the asylum at Abbassieh is being enlarged at a cost of £10,500. A portion of the military hospital adjoining has been made over to the Sanitary tDepartment for the purpose. At present there are already 1,500 patients in the Abbassieh asylum, but for want of,accommodation many cases are awaiting decisions. As a striking proof ot the disastrous effect of hashish smoking among the native population we many remark that nearly 75 per cent. of the cases in the asylum owe their origin to their cause.

div.head: CASHIER ARRESTED.
div.p: A report is current that.the cashier of the Banque d’Athenes was arrested this morning on a charge of embezzling the sum of £2,000 The news has naturally caused a considerable sensation in banking and commercial circles in Alexandria. We publish this news, however, under all reserve as we received it too late to obtain any confirmation of the report either from the bank itself, the Gouvernorat, or the Greek consulate.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS, LIMITED.
div.p: The Five per Cent. Second Debenture coupons of the Egyptian Markets, Limited, falling due on the 30th inst, are payable at the Anglo Egyptian Bank, Limited, 27, Cle- ment’s Lane, EC.

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC.
div.p: Daring the month of Augast 848,548 kilos of gum arabic, valued at L.E. 22,034 were ex- ported from Egypt. In the same month of 1904 the exports were 775,348 kilos, of the value of L.E 17,476 ; an increase in 1905 of 72,205 kilos, valne LK 4,558.

From the 1st January to the 31st Augast, 1905, the exports to England and her Medi- terranean possessions were 857,440 kilos, value L.K 20,722 ; Germany 1,524,516 kilos, value LK 36,554 ; Austria-Hungary, 484,303 kilos, valne LE 10,367; France and Algeria, 1,247,300 kilos, valne LE 29,324; Italy, 243,762 kilos, value LR 6,779 ; Turkey, 7,194 kilos, value L.K 171; America, 717,421 kilos, valne L E. 17,169 ; and to other countries 989,157 kilos, value LK 23,814, a decrease in 1905 of 741,523 kilos, value L.E 8,273.

div.head: GRAVE CARRIAGE ACCIDENT.
div.p: A painful accident took place at Fagallah on Friday night. M. J. d’Argila of the Sucreries Company was driving across the Rond Point at Fagallah when an arabeah coming from the opposite direction collided with his carriage. The pole struck M. d’Argila full in the face inflicting painful injuries which necessitated an operation at the Voronoff Hospital at Shoubra. M. d’Argila, who had just returned from Alexandria, where he had been staying with his family, is manager of the Sugar Company's factory at Minieh and has many friends both at Cairo and Alexandria who will be glad to hear that he is progressing as favorably as can be expected.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive will leave Alexandria for lit Cairo on November 9.
Shakonr Pasha will return to Egypt towards I the end of November.
Amongst the arrivals by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat this morning we notice Mabmoud Pasha Sidki, Harari Pasha, and Abdulla Bey Ster.

Captain McMurdo, D.S.O., the director of the Slave Trade Repression Department, returns from leave on the 4th October, when Major Ravenscroft, the assistant director, will proceed on a tour of inspection of the outpost in the Bahr-el-Gazal Province.
El Kaimakam Jackson Bey, offioer com- manding 1st Battalion, Egyptian Army, has been granted leave of absence until Deocember 3.
Mr. and Mrs. George Royle are returning to Egypt by the P. and 0. steamer Moldrvia, leav- ing Marseilles on the 13th proximo.

The approaching marriage is announced of Dr. Charles C. Forrester, assistant inspector of the Sanitary Department, with Miss Adeline Hartnoll, youngest daughter of the late Mr. James Hartnoll, of Potters Bar.
Lieutenant L. S. Coke, Irish Guards, has been selected for service with the Egyptian army.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
BLOWING UP OF THE CHATHAM.
div.p: Confirming my wire of this morning I now send a few of tho more interesting details of this unfortunate affair.

It will be remembered that on the 9th inst Lieutenant Cunningham R A. and Mr. Ringros of the citadel, Cairo, came down here specially to survey and advise the Canal Company on the best methods of dealing with the matter. Their advice, after lengthy discussion and after a consultation held at the scene of the wreck and at Port Said in the presence of Messrs. Reynaud,Smitt,and the chiefs of the engineers’ staff, was that it would be decidedly unsafe to handle the 91 tons of explosives in any way or to subject the vessel to any shocks ; this advice involved the prohibition of any salvage operations which entailed any system of pum- ping as highly dangerous ; the reason being that a large quantity of the dynamite (of which there were over 3,000 cases on board) had by that time become saturated with water, (the holds being full) and had in consequence given out a considerable quantity of nitro-glycerin which, in its turn, had become part and parcel of the water which the holds contained. It was evident, then, that the shocks which pumping would give this mixture would in all probabi- lity cause an explosion and mean the loss of the lives of all in the vicinity. However, it would appear that no decision was at that time definitely taken though preparation was made for eventualities of all kinds. The fresh water canal was barred at several points, togs were held in readiness on the spot, special pilots were sent to assist the navigation, and the canal banks were as far as possible protec- ted. Navigation went on during daylight with few exceptions, captains of ships being com- pelled to sign a declaration which indicated the knowledge of the situation and the risk entailed by ships passing the spot. On Wednes day, Mr. Conllant (L’Agent Principals) Mr. Perrier (L’ingenienr en Chef) and one or two other gentlemen of the canal staff who were sent out specially, arrived here by the Isis from Brindisi, which vessel had on board Mr. H. Harris, the eminent metallurgical chemist of of Messrs. Nobel's factory, and two assistants, Messrs. Cunningham and Thompson.
The vessel reached here early and by 9 a.m. the entire staff here, with those who had recently arrived, were on board the special launch which was to take them to the Chatham.

Arriving on the scene the several members of the commission proceeded to the sunken vessel in boats. Mr. Harris had not been here many minutes, before he discovered bubbles of what appeared to be air rising from the holds, and he at once set about collecting the "air” in glass vessels. The glasses were carefully taken away from the vessel and experiments were made which proved beyond doubt that the "air” was nothing more nor less than hydrogen in an almost pure state. (Hydrogen, though as an element perfectly harmless, becomes highly explosive when mixed with oxygen in the pro- portion of 2 to 1 by volume, owing to their great affinity. Ed. E.Q.) This apparently led the experts to the conclusion that acid was at work on the iron in the ship or her cargo, and the more the acid increases in quantity the more the danger of spontaneeous explosion, owing to the greater quantity of nitroglycerin being subjected to chemical action, for it would appear that this is a substance whose safety only lies in its absolute lack of acid, hence its vary frequent washings in preparation and manufacture.

Deliberations were proceeded with on return t) Port Sald, and the advice of Mr. Harris was wired to Paris. Mr. Tillier arrived on Friday morning and the replies to the telegram would appear to have roached here the same morning, for after a further visit to the wreck, it was decided to prooeed with as little delay as possible to the explosion of the vesseL The day, Thursday next, was finally fixed last night, it being the day after the passage of the P. and 0. mail for India and Australia, and it has been since officially intimated that all traffic is to close on Wednesday evening in order to give the experts full time in which to test currents and lay charges as they require to be, most carefally. Troops have been asked for from Cairo who will form a cordon round the spot in a circle of some six miles diameter, this being apparently a safe distance from which the effect of this monster explosion may watched.

In the opinion of tho expert committee unlikely the shock will be the of much damage in Port Said beyond perhaps a few broken windows for it must collected that there is over 25 feet of water above the explosives and that the canal banks will keep the lateral disturbance largely within bounds. It is not anticipated either that the railway will greatly suffer beyond displacement and loosening of rails, and should the fresh water canal be damaged, which is more than likely, it will, it is hoped, not greatly interfere with the water supply here, as the deviation of the channel to the extent of 220 yards is now completed, so that should the old canal be out up, which is pro- bable, the new channel is hardly likely to suffer appreciably. The ship canal’s east bank will undoubtedly be blown to atoms and the west bank too will probably be badly damaged, but the main trouble is considered by the experts here, who have the matter in hand, to be the effort of the tidal wave may attain practically any proportion, and will probably cause a great deal of da- mage in this harbour unless craft are moored in the roadstead and well dear of each other.

The difficulty in saying beforehand what will actually oocur on Thursday lies in the fact that no semblance even of a criterion exists in the history of explosives, and therefore, though it is probable that the experts have erred on the right side, their calculations are based on pure surmise. The meur- ers of the commission are Messrs. Tillier, Coullant, Schmitt, Reynaud and, Perrier, Doyer, Jusserand, Koenig, Harri', Cunningham, and Thompson.

(From another Correspondent). Intense excitement has been evident in Port Said since the committee of experts finally decided to blow op the Chatham. There is, of course, much speculation as to what the effects of such an enormous explosion are likely to be, and some of the inhabitants anti- cipate the event with most ridiculous terror. The shock will, of of course, be felt in the town but there is very little danger of any serious damage being done as the sunken vessel is nineteen kilometres away. Meanwhile prepara- tions are being made for the blowing up of the vessel, and I learn on good authority that the batteries for the generation of the electric power have already been fixed at Kantars, which is some twenty-two kilometres from the position of the Chatham.

The railway authorities anticipate the loos- ening of the rails, and have made arrange- ments for the work of relaying them to be started as soon as possible after the explosion, They have over a thousand bags of sand in readiness and as a large gang of workmen will work on the line without a pause traffic is not likely to be very seriously delayed.

I do not know whether any steps are being taken for a temporary telegraph line to be laid sufficiently far from the scene of the explosion to be rendered safe from destruction, but as those which run along the railway are almost certain to be thrown down by the force of the explosion for a considerable distance it is to be hoped that provision is being made for the maintenance of telegraphs communication between here and the rest of Egypt, especially as the mails will be greatly delayed.

It is difficult to ascertain exactly what weight of dynamite will be exploded. First reports gave the amount as 70 tons, which was said to be the amount which appeared in the manifest, and then came the story that there was at least 120 tons aboard. Probably 100 tons is an approximately accurate estimate,but after all the explosion will be so terrible that a few tons more or less will make but little difference.

div.head: NAVAL NOTES.
div.p: H.M.S. Sirius, contrary to expectations, did not receive orders at Suez to proceed to enquire into the Red Sea piracies ; she transitted the Canal shortly after her arrival at Suez and arrived here yesterday, leaving for Malta and home at noon to-day.

Yesterday afternoon one of the hydrographic department (French) corvettes arrived in from sea acoompanied by the new armoured cruiser Dupetit Thouars, en route for the East. She was to have entered the Canal to-day, but owing to the large number of vessels coming from Suez is to remain here to-night.

The Dupetit Thouarsisan armoured cruiser of comparatively recent type and great offensive power. Displacing 9,616 metric tons she is capable of a speed of 21 knots per hour at forced draught, and has a maximum radius of action of 10,000 miles at ten knots speed, While her armour protection is less thorough than that of the Japanese vessels of the Asama type, and the latest British, French, and German armoured cruiser, her armament is proportionately very powerful, comprising two in. q.f. in turrets, eight 6.4 q.f. in casemates, r 3.9 in. q f. in shields, twenty-two small quick firers and two submerged torpedo tubes. was built at Toulon and was launched July 5,1901.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: MR. R. M. HANSARD, We deeply regret to announce the death of Mr. Hansard, which occurred at 11 a.m. on Saturday, at the Anglo-American hospital, from typhoid fever. Mr. Hansard,who was only 33 years of age, was educated at Malvern and at Oriel College, Oxford. He came out to Egypt in January 1902,to join the Survey Department as inspector.

The funeral, at which many of the friends and colleagues of the deceased were present, took place at the English cemetery at 4.30 p.m. yesterday. We offer our most sincere condolences to the relatives and to the many friends of the deceased, at the sad loss they sustained, and the premature close of a most promising career.

div.head: PRIVATE LECKE.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Private Locke 2nd Royal Berkshire Regt. who fell from a troop train near Damanhour, while pro- ceeding to Khartoum on Saturday the 23rd inst., and was killed on the spot. The military funeral took place at Alexandria yesterday.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN NILE STEAMERS Hotel Company River transport of goods between Alexandria and Cairo Three Sailings a Week
Frederic Ruhland
div.p: Samedi, eu ouvrant l’audience du Tribunal Mixe de Justice Sommaire de cette ville, M. le Président Carl Otto Montan a, devant on public nombreux, rendu un dernier et solennel hommage à la mémoire du regretté magistrat français M. Frédéric Ruhland, on termes émue, et empreints d'uno vive et sincère douleur.

M. le Président s’est exprimé ainsi : Messieurs, Au moment où les vacances judiciaires ap- prochent de leur fin, et qu’on espérait revoir en pleine vigueur tous ceux qui étaient partis pour se reposer de leurs fatigues et se préparer aux travaux futurs, une dépéche nous annonce la mort subite d’un des membres de notre Tribu- nal, de celui qui pendant assez longtemps pré- sida a cette Chambre même, M. Frédéric Ruhland.
Ce n'est qu'il y a quatre ans a peine que M. Ruhland quitta son siège a la Cour d'Appel de Paris pour devenir un des représentants de la France aux Tribunaux Mixtes.

Rien ne faisait prévoir que la vie de ce magistrat digne et intègre touchât à sa fin. S'il était d’un âge un peu avancé il ne paraissait pas toutefois décliner vers la vieillesse. Et c'était en parfaite santé qu'il nous quitta il y a quelques mois.
C'est ctte Chambre qui spécialement a été à méme d’apprécier tant son amour du travail et son empressement à l'accomplir, que sa haute capacité et son sentiment prononcé de la Justice.
D autre part, par sa droiture et sa franchise, par son amabilité, sa bonté et sa simplicité, M. Ruhland avait acquis aussi en Egypte, l'estime et les sympathies de tous.
Sa disparition laissera dans nos coeurs un grand .vide en même temps que la magistra- ture mixte en éprouve une perte des plus sen- sibles.
Au nom de ses collegues j'ai voulu a cette occasion donner une expression de la profonde douleur que sa mort nous a causée et rendre un hommage bien mérité k sa mémoire.

Au nom du parquet Général Mixte, M. le Substitut, Mohamed bey Abdel Latif El Kor- chyd, s’est associé aux paroles prononcées par M. le Président d'audience en disant la part très grande que lui et ses collègues prennent au deuil qui frappe la Magistrature Mixte.
M. Frédéric W. Simond, Substitut du Bâ- tonnier de l'Ordre des Avocats, a ensuite de- mandé la parole et au nom du Barreau Mixte, il a prononcé le discoursque nous reproduisons ci-dessous.

Monsieur le Président, Le Barreau a appris avec stupeur la mort subite de l'éminent magistrat qui, il y a quel- ques jours à peine, nous quittait pour aller dans son pays chercher le repos, après le dur labeur de l’hiver.

Jeune encore, M. Ruhland semblait devoir parcourir une longue carrière et il paralt im- possible que la mort impitoyable l'ait enlevé de ce siège qu’il aimait tant, et où nous avons eu si souvent l’occasion d’admirer ses hautes qua- tés de magistrat et d'homme du monde.
Vous avez dit, Monsieur le Président, ta, science juridique et la netteté de son esprit si fortement cultivé.

Il m’appartient d’évoquer son souvenir pour remercier sa mémoire de l'affabilité exquise et de l'extrême courtoisie dont il a toujours fait preuve dans ses rapporte avec nous. Nul de nous n'oubliera jamais sa cordiale poignée de main ni son affectueux sourire. Aussi, o’eit le ocêur serré que je me joins aux paroles que vous avez prononcées et que j'unis le Barreau k la Magistrature pour déplorer ce nouveau deuil qui nous frappe tous et met un voile de tristesse sur cette audience de Justice Som- maire, oh plane encore son bon esprit et ta douce autorité.
Je vous prie. Monsieur le Président, de prendre acte de la profonde sympathie du Barreau ainsi qne de ses regrets attristés.
L'audience a été alors suspendue pendant quelques instants en signe de deuil.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE ( Aviourd midi et demis)

Les obsèques ont eu lieu ce matin a 10 heures et demie au milieu d’une grande affluence de parents et d'amis.
Nous adressons k tous ceux que cette mort atteint dans leurs affections, dos meilleurs souhaits de condoléances.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE AVIS IMPORTANT.
div.p: La Municipalité croit devoir rappeler au public que d'après l’art. 9 du décret de 1884 sur l’impôt de la propriété bâtie, tout proprié- taire faisant de nouvelles constructions, addi- tions ou retranchements à ses immeubles doit sous peine de douhle imposition, aviser la Municipalité par écrit sous pli recommandé avant le 15 novembre de chaque année.

A la suite de nombreuses réclamations pour dégrèvement d'amendes infligées pour non-avis de nouvelles constructions, la Délegation Mu- nicipale a décidé qu'aucune réclamation à ce sujef sons prétexte d’ignorance de la loi ne sera prise en considération.
Le Vice-Président (signé) Ambroise A Ralli. Alexandrie, le 25 Septembre 1905. 26473-3-1

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 25 1905. ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB SEPTEMBER SKYE MEETING.
div.p: Saturday's Skye Meeting in spite of bright and cool weather was not largely attended, large proportion of the residents of Alexandria being absent in Europe. The entries, except in the first race were not very large. Khalil Pasha Khayat took two firsts and a third while the other successes were fairly equally divided.The last race produced a most exciting finish Mirzaud and Jupiter running a dead beat. The bari Loutuel did not pay very brilliantly,except in the first race and on Jupiter as a (tie) winner in the sixth. The Band of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regt. conducted by Bandmaster Gore, played an excellent selection of music during the afternoon, which was much appre- ciated.
The following are the resnlts of the varions events.

A most exciting race. Jupiter led at the start, Mirzand, close behind him, was clearly a length behind half way. On coming out of the bend Jupiter bad gained, and seem- ed a clear length ahead, while Saiad was close behind Mizzaud. The barb, however, had plenty left in him and coming grandly up the straight caught Jupiter some twenty yards from the post and came in dead lex el. Saiad was a good third.
Totalisator paid on winners, Jupiter 142, Mizzand 20. Places. Jupiter 44, Mizzaud 25, 3rd horse 44.

div.head: THE JAPANESE NAVY.
div.p: A cheery chronicle of some incidents in the late war, and of the part taken by himself as a volunteer naval officer, is to be found in Mr. H. C. Seppings Wright’s ‘ Story of Seven Months’ Active Service" with the Japanese Fleet before Port Arthur. Mr. Wright seems to have held a brief to witch operations on behalf of the great Armstrong firm, from whose works at Elswick have come forth so much of the armament that aided Japan to gain her successes on the seas. The voyage out gave the artist-correspondent his first taste of war matters ; for among his fellow-travellers were some Japanese officers. One, Captain Sakai, was on his way home from St Petersburg, where he had been stationed.—

"He was a quiet, somewhat reserved man, and seemed really sorry that the war had broken out. “I have so many friends in St. Petersburg,’ he said, and only recently I said "good bye" to Admiral Makarof, who,’ he added, with rather a sad smile, ‘hopes to meet me in the Far East’ ”

Mr. Wright tells as that the disunities attending war-correspondents bound for the front on land were as nothing to those awaiting the audacious foreigner who sought to see something of the naval actions. But his own case was backed by the Armstrong interest, and he facilitated compliance by offering him- self for active service—a petition that was by and by considered favorably. Meanwhile, he was lucky enough to he invited to form one of a favored party going from Tokio to the neighbourhood of Port Arthur in a steamship. This excursion was to be "a sort of Govern- ment picnic on a large scale’’—planned, one shrewdly suspects, with the object of keeping restless correspondents amused and out of mischief. At Sasebo, the guests were allowed to inspect dockyards, arsenals, stores, and hospitals, and to make the acquaintance of the Commander-in chief, Admiral Samijima. Che- mulpo and Seoul were visited: and an audience was granted by His Majesty of Korea. Mr. Wright’s pages are full of lively description, and it is clear that the picnickers enjoyed a thoroughly pleasant trip. Most impressive did our author find his first sight of “A certain place’’—i.e., Togo’s secret base ; and of Togo himself be made the acquaintance on board his flagship, the ill-fated Mikasa, the destruction of which, by a sad coincidence, marks the day of Mr. Wright's publication.

Back at Tokio, Mr. Wright found his luck held, and he was duly accepted as a volunteer in the service of the Emperor of Japan. Ap- pointed in an auxiliary cruiser, he saw some- thing of the daily round aboard a vessel of this class, and noted in what manner it differed from our own naval routine. The Jap sailors won his heart:—

"They stand about knitting, if nothing else is to be done. They are never idle, and are always merry and good tempered. There is never any punishment, for none is ever merit- ed. Each man feels that his particular job is as necessary to Japan as Admiral Togo himself, and they are all inspired by one sentiment— 'Bushido,' the literal meaning of which is ‘duty and patriotism.’ ”

The English critio appears to hava found plenty to admire ; and be selects for men- tion a few of the points wherein ha consider- ed the Japanese naval organisation especially admirable. Por ins tan oe :—

"All food undergoes the strictest inspection, not only before, but after it is cooked. Every day the quartermaster brings in a dish of the men’s food—taken haphazard from the coppers which the paymaster and the doctor taste and inspect, and the same system is applied to the food destined for the ward-room, so that all on board have only the most wholesome food set before them. This excellent system is also enforced is the army. . . . Walking round the ship I noticed that two very useful boats of the sampan type were carried. Needle- nosed and flat-bottomed, they are propelled by sculling at the side, and are perfect for land- ing troops. They are capable of holding a fair number of men, who squat on the bottom out of the way of the scullers ; and drawing very little water, they nan go dose to the shore, thus enabling the men to effect a dry landing. This is one of the secret* of the Japanese success in putting a large army on shore, as all the ships carry these boats."
Mr. Wright was struck, also, by the custom of sending the purser and the doctor, as soon as a ship’s anchor was down, to the harbour- master’s ship "to report arrival and to receive instructions " :—
" All ships on the way to the front report themselves at various signal-stations on the journey, and when they pass near a base they call in for further orders.’
In this way they leave and receive the latest news, and are in constant touch with officials at headquarters.

The extreme cleanliness of the Jap sailors is extended, we learn, to the outside of their vessels, which are never allowed to become foul. The thoroughness with which the men acour and paint the bottoms of their ships is sometimes not a little awkward for those on dock ; as Mr. Wright describes amusingly later on. While with the cruiser at Dalny he heard the news of Liaoyang, and the story of the sinking of the Novik at Saghalien.

Transferred to an auxiliary cruiser at Dalny, and thence to torpedo-boat No. 67,Mr. Wright found himself at last at work within Togo’s lines. His own duties were light, and he met with the greatest kindness from everyone—in- including Togo himself. The fleet was lying be- fore Port Arthur, waiting for the general assault to take place, on land, which “it was hoped would drive the Russians into Togo's arms." The torpedo-boat's daily "24 hours’ brat" soon grew monotonous to Mr. Wright— diversified as it was by occasional experience* of a sterner sort; and he petitioned for leave to go ashore and pitch his tent within sight of the struggle. Permission was granted, and a spot chosen on a hill where a camp could be established just outside the fighting tone. There Mr. Wright posted himself with his guard and his attendants, and there he passed a month very comfortably (barring accidents) in painting and prospecting and viewing the distant fighting ; carefully watched over by his interested friends in the fleet—who, they assured him, were "responsible to Togo for his safety." Another period on board No. 67 was made even livelier than usnal by the fesivites— graphically described—of the Em- peror of Japan's birthday.

The fall of Port Arthur being imminent Mr. Wright obtained leave to return to his old ship at Dalny ; and thence, when the surrender had actually taken place, he journeyed to the scene of the great struggle. On the way he was the guest of Ichinohe—"the gallant officer who, sword in hand, was wont to spring to the heed of his troops and personally lead them to the attack’’— and visited' the horrible desola- tion of Double Dragon Fort.

Port Arthur at this juncture has been de- scribed by many pens ; not the latest is at least as capable as any. The admirable order immediately introduced by the Japanese occupiers (who seemed to have thought of and prepared for everything), and their fine courtesy to the defeated side, have become a familiar tale. Mr. Wright is more interesting when he takes us to visit the Russian battle- ships sank in the harbour, and 203 Metre HOI "of tragic memory." It is almost a pity that this is practically the end of our author's narrative ; for here, at least, he sapped fall of horrors, and the recital breaks dramatically the generally light-hearted style in which he has couched by far the greater part of his story. His return to Tokio concluded his ad ventures in the East. He has made of them a book that mingles most attractively informa- tion and entertainment; and while those familiar with our own Service will be gratified by his notes and news about the Japanese Navy from a professional point of view, less instructed readers will discover many pleasing pictures showing the purely human side of the gallant fellows who defend the shores of the land of the Rising Sun.
Mr. Seppings Wright’s excellent drawings and photographs illustrate the volume, which is published in neat guise by Messrs. Hurst and Blackett.

div.head: MONT PELLE BY NIGHT.
div.p: We saw Mont Pelee at midnight and from the sea. The steamer had threaded its way through the tangle of islands to the north, each beautiful in form and colour beyond expression, and had come at last te Dominice, perhaps the most perfect of alL It is but a stone’s throw from Martinique, the focus of fire and destruction, but as we cleared the road- stead of Rousean at sundown it looked, in the warm light, like a pictures of peace becalmed. From the dip of the land into the sea to the high mornes that caught the clouds it was green with verdure and aflame with flower. The heat haze of the day simmered about it, airy iridescent, and the atmosphere was still with the intense stillness that follows the dying away of the sea wind. One is not long in the tropics before he realises that quietude is the prevailing note of Nature there ; it interpenetrates the gorgeous phenomena of the day, and it makes night incomparable in its cool repose. To it this region of the world owes much of its healing power, and not a little of its glamour and mystery. For day will follow day, and night succed night, in even proces- sion, for a decade, and then a paroxysm, as fierce as it is sodden, will seise it, and change the fair heaven of its appearance into a desola- tion as of hell.

As the vessel steamed into the open sea the night came, serene and dear, and radiant with stars. At intervals silent lightning flared up from some quarter beyond the horison, mo- mentarily flooding the seascape with violet Later, over the port bow, in the far distance, appeared a confusion in the sky, where the moon was rising behind clouds, unseen, but aureoled in olive. Straight ahead there rose an uncertain mass, darker than the night, with the Southern Cross not yet end, shining above. When it took more palpable shape we saw, sweeping np from the sea, in vast, magni- ficent outline, the form of Mont Pelce. There was no huddling of summits and shoulders as in the other islands bat one broad base swell- ing into a single needle like peak. The impres- sion of solitude and grandeur which it impart ed was not modified as other peaks farther south, came into view. The base but broadened and the summit rose, dwarfing them all in the majesty and austerity of their profile. The cone was silhouetted against the sky with the sharpness of a photographic negative, like many tropical peaks at night when the air is free from the cloud which the heat and the wind of the day develop. There was nothing to indicate the activity of the forces that still exist and rage far below these upper heights.

Along the coast, lights gleamed from the hamlets among the palm groves, but as we passed to leeward and entered the shadow of the land we approached the volcanic tone, and these kindly glimmerings became fewer, and then ceased. The sea was dead calm, with phosphorescence streaming below the surface.
We steamed so silently that the engine power seemed muffled—we moved as things do in a dream. And always skywards stood out the lonely peak environed by the beauty and mystery of the night

As we looked, there came a swift movement on the summit, and a column of steam, white and ghostlike, swirled op and rose high in the air. The effect was startling in its suddenness, in the contrast which the flying vapour made with the dark, immovable rook, and one gated with fascinated expectancy, not knowing what might follow. The cloud went sporting upwards, but towards the top, where the pressure lessen- ed, it also spread slowly out with a puffing, rolling motion. For a moment it caught a glow as from some strange fire beneath, and took on the likeness of a cross reddened with blood. Then it collapsed and became a mass of shapeless mist that covered the peak and hid it from view.

The moon-clouds broke, and a beam of light, soft and end beautiful shot down and rested upon the mountain side, and by and by the whole land was illumined and revealed. We saw that the ground ascended to the peak in long hollow slopes. There was no appearance, as in the other islands, of rounded masses of vegetation or serrated ridge, hot only of clean, flint-like surface, adamantine and barren. One felt the cool wind that always blows on there islands at night, but here it came unscented with the fragrance of the woods. The light shone on the aretes as on smooth quartz, but left the canons black and impenetrable. One of these, the River Blanche, extended np to the peak, and one could imagine he saw, in the higher folds, the crater which opened that fair Ascen- sion morning and shot out the incandescent blast that annihilated St Pierre.

St Pierre ! There it lies along a bend in the coast at the foot of the southern slopes, soundless because sheltered from the sari that rolls and beats upon the Atlantic side, dreamless because it is a city of the dead. The moonshine of the tropics can do won- derful things. It can transform a swamp into a garden and shabby buildings into palaces, but it cannot make St Pierre anything but what it is—the skeleton of an organism once vivid with life, a thing of rags and tatters, of wreck irretrievable, surcharged with horror and melancholy.

It is too dim to discern details. One sees a jagged strip of ground with short up- rights that recall a cemetery, a hare bluff behind, the shape here and there of a blasted tree, and, higher, the ridges about Moire Rouge, where the area of life again begins. The last glimpse is of a young ba- nana leaf waving slowly in the ashen waste, suggesting the time when Nature, in its in- sistent irresistible way may fertilise the dust and disintegrate the basalt and cover the ruins with bloom.

Midnight was past-the Gross had began to bend. Lights appeared again on the sea level and a cluster farther on, for which we made. One in front—a beacon—dazzled us with its brightness, and then the chains rattled, and we anchored off Fort de France.

div.head: Agricultural Bank of Egypt New Issue of Shares for Increase of Capital
div.p: In Pursuance of an Extraordinary Ge- neral Meeting held on the 18th May 1905 the Board of Directors of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt offer 218,000 new shares of the said Bank of Five pounds serling each. These shares will contstitute an increase of the Capital of the Bank, and are issued in conformity with the Statutes at the price of Five Pounds sterling per share, payable on application.

Application should be made:- in Egypt to the Head Office of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo and to the Branch at Alexandria. In London to the London Agency of the National Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5, King Williams Street, E.C.
The new shares will rank for dividend from the 1st January 1906, that is to say from the beginning of next year.
Every shareholder has the right on applica- tion to an allotment of one new share in respect of every old share held.

All shareholders who wish to exercise their rights must, under pain of forfeiture of those rights, lodge their applications at once of the places named above on or before the 2nd October 1905 depositing their Share Warrants together with the total payable, via: 5 per share.
The President of the Board of directors, (signed) Elwin Palmer Cairo, the 8th July, 1905 26444-5-3
